name: POINTILLISM
blurb: In this project, I used 3/8" birch plywood and Forstner bits to create a pointillism pop-art portait of Guyler Stevens, a fictional character from my novel Pass. "Painting with drills!"  Best viewed from a distance.

name: WIZARDS APPLICATION
blurb: In December of 2014, I applied for a job in the Creative Department working on storylines for the Magic: The Gathering trading card game.  This was a supplemental piece submitted with my application, meant to demonstrate creativity, world-building, and outside-the-box-thinking.

name: FATHER'S DAY
blurb: When I stumbled across a two-page excerpt in Edgar Allan Poe's "The Murders in the Rue Morgue" extolling the virtues of whist and whist players, I knew that I had found the seed of the perfect Father's Day present.  Completed using Inkscape and photos from the Pershing Room at West Point, where my father spent years playing.

name: LIGNIFIED RAPTOR
blurb: One of the final projects in my sixth grade class was a bridge-building challenge with popsicle sticks and hot glue.  By my third year of teaching, I had already constructed multiple example bridges, and instead spent the time between student questions sculpting the bust of a velociraptor.

name: VAULT
blurb: In 2011, my friend Stephanie introduced me to the concept of sculpting with hot glue (laying down layer after layer in a sort of 3D printing).  Using string and paperclips to create a wireframe skeleton, I sculpted a traceur performing a speed vault and skinned it with black airsoft pellets.

name: BEATSTICK
blurb: In my youth, I attended summer camp with the YMCA at Camp Frontier.  It was usually somewhere in the vicinity of 100Â°, and as an antisocial, out-of-shape Star Wars nerd, I didn't end up hanging out with the other boys very often.  The girls, however, were braiding lanyards in the shade during tennis, and that was about my speed.
